Drug_Medication: Any drug prescribed without a clinical indication.
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Any drug prescribed without a clinical indication.

Drug_Medication: Any drug prescribed beyond the recommended duration,
Condition_Disease: where treatment duration is well defined.
Full_Text: Any drug prescribed beyond the recommended duration, where treatment duration is well defined.

Condition_Disease: for daily regular use (as distinct from PRN use) e.g., two concurrent NSAIDs, SSRIs, loop diuretics, ACE inhibitors, anticoagulants, antipsychotics, opioid analgesics
Rationale_Reason: optimisation of monotherapy within a single drug class should be observed prior to considering a new agent
Full_Text: Any duplicate drug class prescription for daily regular use (as distinct from PRN use) e.g., two concurrent NSAIDs, SSRIs, loop diuretics, ACE inhibitors, anticoagulants, antipsychotics, opioid analgesics (optimisation of monotherapy within a single drug class should be observed prior to considering a new agent).

Condition_Disease: for heart failure with normal systolic ventricular function
Full_Text: Digoxin for heart failure with normal systolic ventricular function (no clear evidence of benefit)

Condition_Disease: with NYHA Class III or IV heart failure
Rationale_Reason: may worsen heart failure with reduced ejection fraction i.e., HFREF
Full_Text: Verapamil or diltiazem with NYHA Class III or IV heart failure (may worsen heart failure with reduced ejection fraction i.e., HFREF).

Condition_Disease: in combination with verapamil or diltiazem
Full_Text: Beta-blocker in combination with verapamil or diltiazem (risk of heart block).

Drug_Medication: Ventricular rate-limiting drugs i.e., beta blocker, verapamil, diltiazem, digoxin
Condition_Disease: with bradycardia (< 50/min), type II heart block or complete heart block
Rationale_Reason: risk of complete heart block, asystole
Full_Text: Ventricular rate-limiting drugs i.e., beta blocker, verapamil, diltiazem, digoxin with bradycardia (< 50/min), type II heart block or complete heart block (risk of complete heart block, asystole).

Condition_Disease: for uncomplicated hypertension i.e., not associated with angina pectoris, aortic aneurysm or other condition where beta-blocker therapy is indicated
Full_Text: Beta-blocker as monotherapy for uncomplicated hypertension i.e., not associated with angina pectoris, aortic aneurysm or other condition where beta-blocker therapy is indicated (no firm evidence of efficacy).

Condition_Disease: in supraventricular tachyarrhythmias
Rationale_Reason: higher risk of major side-effects than beta-blockers, digoxin, verapamil or diltiazem
Full_Text: Amiodarone as first-line antiarrhythmic therapy in supraventricular tachyarrhythmias (higher risk of major side-effects than beta-blockers, digoxin, verapamil or diltiazem).

Condition_Disease: for hypertension unless there is concurrent heart failure requiring diuretic therapy
Full_Text: Loop diuretic as first-line treatment for hypertension unless there is concurrent heart failure requiring diuretic therapy (safer, more effective alternatives available).

Condition_Disease: for dependent ankle oedema without clinical, biochemical or radiological evidence of heart failure, liver failure, nephrotic syndrome or renal failure
Rationale_Reason: leg elevation and /or compression hosiery usually more appropriate
Full_Text: Loop diuretic for dependent ankle oedema without clinical, biochemical or radiological evidence of heart failure, liver failure, nephrotic syndrome or renal failure (leg elevation and /or compression hosiery usually more appropriate). 1

Condition_Disease: with current significant hypokalaemia (i.e., serum K+ < 3.0 mmol/l), hyponatraemia (i.e., serum Na+ < 130 mmol/l) hypercalcaemia (i.e., corrected serum calcium > 2.65 mmol/l) or with a history of gout
Rationale_Reason: hypokalaemia, hyponatraemia, hypercalcaemia and gout can be precipitated by thiazide diuretic
Full_Text: Thiazide diuretic with current significant hypokalaemia (i.e., serum K+ < 3.0 mmol/l), hyponatraemia (i.e., serum Na+ < 130 mmol/l) hypercalcaemia (i.e., corrected serum calcium > 2.65 mmol/l) or with a history of gout (hypokalaemia, hyponatraemia, hypercalcaemia and gout can be precipitated by thiazide diuretic)

Condition_Disease: for treatment of hypertension with concurrent urinary incontinence
Full_Text: Loop diuretic for treatment of hypertension with concurrent urinary incontinence (may exacerbate incontinence).

Drug_Medication: Centrally-acting antihypertensives e.g., methyldopa, clonidine, moxonidine, rilmenidine, guanfacine
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Rationale_Reason: centrally-active antihypertensives are generally less well tolerated by older people than younger people
Full_Text: Centrally-acting antihypertensives e.g., methyldopa, clonidine, moxonidine, rilmenidine, guanfacine (centrally-active antihypertensives are generally less well tolerated by older people than younger people)

Drug_Medication: Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) or Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) or Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) in patients with hyperkalaemia i.e., serum K > 5.5 mmol/l.

Condition_Disease: with concurrent potassium- conserving drugs (e.g., ACEI’s, ARB’s, amiloride, triamterene) without monitoring of serum potassium
Rationale_Reason: risk of dangerous hyperkalaemia i.e., > 6.0 mmol/l – serum K should be monitored regularly, i.e., at least every 6 months
Full_Text: Aldosterone antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) with concurrent potassium- conserving drugs (e.g., ACEI’s, ARB’s, amiloride, triamterene) without monitoring of serum potassium (risk of dangerous hyperkalaemia i.e., > 6.0 mmol/l – serum K should be monitored regularly, i.e., at least every 6 months).

Drug_Medication: Phosphodiesterase type-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil)
Condition_Disease: in severe heart failure characterised by hypotension i.e., systolic BP < 90 mmHg, or concurrent nitrate therapy for angina
Full_Text: Phosphodiesterase type-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil) in severe heart failure characterised by hypotension i.e., systolic BP < 90 mmHg, or concurrent nitrate therapy for angina (risk of cardiovascular collapse).

Drug_Medication: Drugs that predictably prolong the QTc interval (QTc = QT/RR)
Condition_Disease: in patients with known with demonstrable QTc prolongation (to >450 msec in males and >470 msec in females), including quinolones, macrolides, ondansetron, citalopram (doses > 20 mg/day), escitalopram (doses > 10 mg/day), tricyclic antidepressants, lithium, haloperidol, digoxin, class 1A antiarrhythmics, class III antiarrhythmics, tizanidine, phenothiazines, astemizole, mirabegron
Rationale_Reason: risk of life- threatening ventricular arrhythmias
Full_Text: Drugs that predictably prolong the QTc interval (QTc = QT/RR) in patients with known with demonstrable QTc prolongation (to >450 msec in males and >470 msec in females), including quinolones, macrolides, ondansetron, citalopram (doses > 20 mg/day), escitalopram (doses > 10 mg/day), tricyclic antidepressants, lithium, haloperidol, digoxin, class 1A antiarrhythmics, class III antiarrhythmics, tizanidine, phenothiazines, astemizole, mirabegron (risk of life- threatening ventricular arrhythmias).

Condition_Disease: for primary cardiovascular prevention in persons aged ≥ 85 and established frailty with expected life expectancy likely less than 3 years
Full_Text: Statins for primary cardiovascular prevention in persons aged ≥ 85 and established frailty with expected life expectancy likely less than 3 years (lack of evidence of efficacy).

Condition_Disease: with known history of coronary, cerebral or peripheral vascular disease
Full_Text: Long-term systemic i.e., non-topical NSAIDs with known history of coronary, cerebral or peripheral vascular disease (increased risk of thrombosis).

Condition_Disease: with known history of coronary, cerebral or peripheral vascular disease
Full_Text: Long-term antipsychotics with known history of coronary, cerebral or peripheral vascular disease (increased risk of thrombosis).

Condition_Disease: with heart failure requiring loop diuretic therapy
Rationale_Reason: risk of exacerbation of heart failure
Full_Text: NSAIDs or systemic corticosteroids with heart failure requiring loop diuretic therapy (risk of exacerbation of heart failure).

Condition_Disease: in severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
Full_Text: Antihypertensive drugs in severe symptomatic aortic stenosis (risk of severe hypotension, syncope).

Condition_Disease: for long-term (> 3 months) ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation
Rationale_Reason: increased mortality from long-term digoxin use; cardio-selective beta-blockers are generally preferable
Full_Text: Digoxin as first line treatment for long-term (> 3 months) ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation (increased mortality from long-term digoxin use; cardio-selective beta-blockers are generally preferable). 2

Drug_Medication: Long-term aspirin at doses greater than 100mg per day
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Rationale_Reason: increased risk of bleeding, no evidence for increased efficacy
Full_Text: Long-term aspirin at doses greater than 100mg per day (increased risk of bleeding, no evidence for increased efficacy).

Drug_Medication: Antiplatelet agents, vitamin K antagonists, direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors
Condition_Disease: with concurrent significant risk of major bleeding, i.e. uncontrolled severe hypertension, bleeding diathesis, recent non-trivial spontaneous bleeding
Full_Text: Antiplatelet agents, vitamin K antagonists, direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors with concurrent significant risk of major bleeding, i.e. uncontrolled severe hypertension, bleeding diathesis, recent non-trivial spontaneous bleeding (high risk of bleeding).

Drug_Medication: Aspirin plus clopidogrel as long-term secondary stroke prevention i.e., > 4 weeks,
Condition_Disease: unless the patient has a coronary stent(s) inserted in the previous 12 months or concurrent acute coronary syndrome or has a high grade symptomatic carotid arterial stenosis
Rationale_Reason: no evidence of added long-term benefit over clopidogrel monotherapy
Full_Text: Aspirin plus clopidogrel as long-term secondary stroke prevention i.e., > 4 weeks, unless the patient has a coronary stent(s) inserted in the previous 12 months or concurrent acute coronary syndrome or has a high grade symptomatic carotid arterial stenosis (no evidence of added long-term benefit over clopidogrel monotherapy).

Condition_Disease: in combination with vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation, unless there is concurrent coronary artery stent(s) inserted or angiographically proven high grade (> 50%) coronary artery stenosis
Rationale_Reason: no added benefit from antiplatelet agents
Full_Text: Antiplatelet agents in combination with vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation, unless there is concurrent coronary artery stent(s) inserted or angiographically proven high grade (> 50%) coronary artery stenosis (no added benefit from antiplatelet agents).

Condition_Disease: with vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors in patients with stable coronary, cerebrovascular or peripheral arterial disease
Rationale_Reason: no evidence of added benefit from dual therapy
Full_Text: Antiplatelet agents with vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors in patients with stable coronary, cerebrovascular or peripheral arterial disease (no evidence of added benefit from dual therapy).

Condition_Disease: in any circumstances
Rationale_Reason: clopidogrel and prasugrel have similar efficacy, stronger evidence and fewer side-effects
Full_Text: Ticlopidine in any circumstances (clopidogrel and prasugrel have similar efficacy, stronger evidence and fewer side-effects).

Drug_Medication: Antiplatelet agents as alternatives to vitamin K antagonists, direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors
Condition_Disease: for stroke prevention in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation
Full_Text: Antiplatelet agents as alternatives to vitamin K antagonists, direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors for stroke prevention in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation (no evidence of efficacy).

Drug_Medication: Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors
Condition_Disease: for first deep venous thrombosis without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g., thrombophilia) for longer than 6 months,
Full_Text: Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors for first deep venous thrombosis without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g., thrombophilia) for longer than 6 months, (no proven added benefit).

Drug_Medication: Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors
Condition_Disease: for first pulmonary embolus without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g., thrombophilia) for longer than 12 months
Full_Text: Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors for first pulmonary embolus without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g., thrombophilia) for longer than 12 months (no proven added benefit).

Drug_Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors
Condition_Disease: in combination
Full_Text: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitors in combination (risk of major gastrointestinal bleeding).

Drug_Medication: Vitamin K antagonist as first-line anticoagulant
Condition_Disease: for atrial fibrillation, unless there is concurrent metallic heart valve in-situ, moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis, or eGFR < 15 mls/min./1.73m2
Rationale_Reason: direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors are equally efficacious and safer than vitamin K antagonists
Full_Text: Vitamin K antagonist as first-line anticoagulant for atrial fibrillation, unless there is concurrent metallic heart valve in-situ, moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis, or eGFR < 15 mls/min./1.73m2 (direct thrombin inhibitors or factor Xa inhibitors are equally efficacious and safer than vitamin K antagonists).

Condition_Disease: in combination with Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitor with a previous history of major haemorrhage
Rationale_Reason: increased risk of bleeding due to antiplatelet effects of SSRIs
Full_Text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in combination with Vitamin K antagonist, direct thrombin inhibitor or factor Xa inhibitor with a previous history of major haemorrhage (increased risk of bleeding due to antiplatelet effects of SSRIs). 3

Drug_Medication: Direct thrombin inhibitor (e.g., dabigatran) and diltiazem or verapamil
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Direct thrombin inhibitor (e.g., dabigatran) and diltiazem or verapamil (increased risk of bleeding).

Drug_Medication: Apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban, rivaroxaban and P-glycoprotein (P-gp) drug efflux pump inhibitors e.g., amiodarone, azithromycin, carvedilol, cyclosporin, dronedarone, itraconazole, ketoconazole (systemic), macrolides, quinine, ranolazine, tamoxifen, ticagrelor, verapamil
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban, rivaroxaban and P-glycoprotein (P-gp) drug efflux pump inhibitors e.g., amiodarone, azithromycin, carvedilol, cyclosporin, dronedarone, itraconazole, ketoconazole (systemic), macrolides, quinine, ranolazine, tamoxifen, ticagrelor, verapamil (increased risk of bleeding).

Condition_Disease: with pervious history of venous thromboembolism
Rationale_Reason: increased risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism
Full_Text: Systemic oestrogens or androgens with pervious history of venous thromboembolism (increased risk of recurrent venous thromboembolism).

Condition_Disease: for primary prevention in cardiovascular disease
Full_Text: Aspirin for primary prevention in cardiovascular disease (no evidence of benefit).

Condition_Disease: in patients with dementia, narrow angle glaucoma, cardiac conduction abnormalities, prostatism, chronic constipation, recent falls, prior history of urinary retention or orthostatic hypotension
Full_Text: TriCyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) in patients with dementia, narrow angle glaucoma, cardiac conduction abnormalities, prostatism, chronic constipation, recent falls, prior history of urinary retention or orthostatic hypotension (risk of worsening these conditions).

Drug_Medication: Initiation of TriCyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) as first-line treatment
Condition_Disease: for major depression
Rationale_Reason: higher risk of adverse drug reactions with TCAs than with SSRIs or SNRIs
Full_Text: Initiation of TriCyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) as first-line treatment for major depression (higher risk of adverse drug reactions with TCAs than with SSRIs or SNRIs).

Drug_Medication: Serotonin/noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRI’s e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine) and severe hypertension i.e., systolic blood pressure > 180 mmHg +/- diastolic blood pressure > 105 mmHg
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Serotonin/noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRI’s e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine) and severe hypertension i.e., systolic blood pressure > 180 mmHg +/- diastolic blood pressure > 105 mmHg (likely to make hypertension worse).

Condition_Disease: with moderate-marked antimuscarinic/anticholinergic effects (acepromazine, chlorpromazine, clozapine, flupenthixol, fluphenzine, levomepromazine, olanzapine, pipothiazine, promazine, thioridazine) with a history of lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia or previous urinary retention
Full_Text: Antipsychotics with moderate-marked antimuscarinic/anticholinergic effects (acepromazine, chlorpromazine, clozapine, flupenthixol, fluphenzine, levomepromazine, olanzapine, pipothiazine, promazine, thioridazine) with a history of lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia or previous urinary retention (high risk of urinary retention).

Condition_Disease: for behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) an unchanged dose for > 3 months without medication review
Rationale_Reason: increased risk of extrapyramidal side-effects and chronic worsening of cognition, increased risk of major cardiovascular morbidity and mortality
Full_Text: Antipsychotics prescribed for behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) an unchanged dose for > 3 months without medication review (increased risk of extrapyramidal side-effects and chronic worsening of cognition, increased risk of major cardiovascular morbidity and mortality).

Condition_Disease: with current or recent significant hyponatraemia i.e., serum Na+ < 130 mmol/l
Rationale_Reason: risk of exacerbating or precipitating hyponatraemia
Full_Text: Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRI’s) with current or recent significant hyponatraemia i.e., serum Na+ < 130 mmol/l (risk of exacerbating or precipitating hyponatraemia).

Condition_Disease: with current or recent significant bleeding
Rationale_Reason: risk of exacerbation or recurrence of bleeding due to antiplatelet effects of SSRI’s
Full_Text: Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRI’s) with current or recent significant bleeding (risk of exacerbation or recurrence of bleeding due to antiplatelet effects of SSRI’s).

Condition_Disease: for ≥ 4 weeks
Rationale_Reason: no indication for longer treatment; risk of prolonged sedation, confusion, impaired balance, falls, road traffic accidents; all benzodiazepines should be withdrawn gradually if taken for more than 4 weeks as there is a risk of causing a benzodiazepine withdrawal syndrome if stopped abruptly
Full_Text: Benzodiazepines for ≥ 4 weeks (no indication for longer treatment; risk of prolonged sedation, confusion, impaired balance, falls, road traffic accidents; all benzodiazepines should be withdrawn gradually if taken for more than 4 weeks as there is a risk of causing a benzodiazepine withdrawal syndrome if stopped abruptly). 4

Condition_Disease: for agitated behaviour or psychotic symptoms of dementia
Full_Text: Benzodiazepines for agitated behaviour or psychotic symptoms of dementia (no evidence of efficacy).

Condition_Disease: for insomnia for ≥ 2 weeks
Rationale_Reason: high risk of dependency, increased risk of falls, fractures and road traffic accidents
Full_Text: Benzodiazepines for insomnia for ≥ 2 weeks (high risk of dependency, increased risk of falls, fractures and road traffic accidents).

Condition_Disease: for insomnia for ≥ 2 weeks
Full_Text: Z-drugs (zolpidem, zopiclone, zaleplon) for insomnia for ≥ 2 weeks (increased risk of falls, fractures).

Drug_Medication: Antipsychotics (i.e., other than clozapine or quetiapine)
Condition_Disease: in those with parkinsonism or Dementia with Lewy Bodies
Full_Text: Antipsychotics (i.e., other than clozapine or quetiapine) in those with parkinsonism or Dementia with Lewy Bodies (risk of severe extra-pyramidal symptoms).

Drug_Medication: Anticholinergic/antimuscarinic drugs (biperiden, orphenadrine, procyclidine, trihexyphenidyl) to treat extra-pyramidal side-effects of antipsychotic medications
Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified
Full_Text: Anticholinergic/antimuscarinic drugs (biperiden, orphenadrine, procyclidine, trihexyphenidyl) to treat extra-pyramidal side-effects of antipsychotic medications (risk of anticholinergic toxicity).

Condition_Disease: with potent anticholinergics/antimuscarinic effects** in patients with delirium or dementia (risk of exacerbation of cognitive impairment). ** Commonly prescribed drugs with potent anticholinergic/ antimuscarinic effects include tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, doxepin, impramine, nortriptyline), antipsychotics (chlorpromazine, clozapine, thioridazine), first generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine), bladder anti-spasmodics
Full_Text: Drugs with potent anticholinergics/antimuscarinic effects** in patients with delirium or dementia (risk of exacerbation of cognitive impairment). ** Commonly prescribed drugs with potent anticholinergic/ antimuscarinic effects include tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, doxepin, impramine, nortriptyline), antipsychotics (chlorpromazine, clozapine, thioridazine), first generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine), bladder anti-spasmodics (e.g., tolterodine, oxybutynin), hyoscine, procyclidine, benzatropine, tizanidine.

Condition_Disease: in patients with behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) for longer than 12 weeks unless BPSD symptoms are severe and other non- pharmacological treatments have failed
Rationale_Reason: increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction
Full_Text: Antipsychotics in patients with behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) for longer than 12 weeks unless BPSD symptoms are severe and other non- pharmacological treatments have failed (increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction).

Condition_Disease: unless sleep disorder is due to psychosis or BPSD effects of dementia
Rationale_Reason: not recommended in summary of product characteristics; increased risk of confusion, hypotension, extra-pyramidal side effects, falls
Full_Text: Antipsychotics as hypnotics, unless sleep disorder is due to psychosis or BPSD effects of dementia (not recommended in summary of product characteristics; increased risk of confusion, hypotension, extra-pyramidal side effects, falls).

Condition_Disease: with a known history of persistent bradycardia (< 60 beats/min.), heart block or recurrent unexplained syncope
Rationale_Reason: risk of cardiac conduction failure, syncope and injury
Full_Text: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors with a known history of persistent bradycardia (< 60 beats/min.), heart block or recurrent unexplained syncope (risk of cardiac conduction failure, syncope and injury).

Condition_Disease: with concurrent treatment with drugs that induce persistent bradycardia (< 60 beats/min.) such as beta-blockers, digoxin, diltiazem, verapamil
Rationale_Reason: risk of cardiac conduction failure, syncope and injury
Full_Text: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors with concurrent treatment with drugs that induce persistent bradycardia (< 60 beats/min.) such as beta-blockers, digoxin, diltiazem, verapamil (risk of cardiac conduction failure, syncope and injury).

Condition_Disease: with known current or previous seizure disorder
Full_Text: Memantine with known current or previous seizure disorder (increased risk of seizures).

Condition_Disease: in dementia including Gingko Biloba, piracetam, pramiracetam, phenylpiracetam, aniracetam, phosphatidylserine, modafinil, L-theanine, omega-3 fatty acids, panax ginseng, rhodiola, creatine
Full_Text: Nootropics in dementia including Gingko Biloba, piracetam, pramiracetam, phenylpiracetam, aniracetam, phosphatidylserine, modafinil, L-theanine, omega-3 fatty acids, panax ginseng, rhodiola, creatine (no evidence of efficacy).

Condition_Disease: for psychosis or non-cognitive symptoms of dementia, since safer and more efficacious alternatives exist
Rationale_Reason: phenothiazines are sedative, have significant anti-muscarinic toxicity in older people, except for prochlorperazine for 5 nausea/vomiting/vertigo, chlorpromazine for relief of persistent hiccoughs and levomepromazine as an anti-emetic in palliative care
Full_Text: Phenothiazines as first-line treatment for psychosis or non-cognitive symptoms of dementia, since safer and more efficacious alternatives exist (phenothiazines are sedative, have significant anti-muscarinic toxicity in older people, except for prochlorperazine for 5 nausea/vomiting/vertigo, chlorpromazine for relief of persistent hiccoughs and levomepromazine as an anti-emetic in palliative care).

Condition_Disease: for benign essential tremor
Full_Text: Levodopa or dopamine agonists for benign essential tremor (no evidence of efficacy)

Condition_Disease: for treatment of extrapyramidal side-effects of antipsychotics or other forms of drug-induced Parkinsonism
Rationale_Reason: inappropriate prescribing cascade to be avoided
Full_Text: Levodopa or dopamine agonists for treatment of extrapyramidal side-effects of antipsychotics or other forms of drug-induced Parkinsonism (inappropriate prescribing cascade to be avoided).

Condition_Disease: for allergy or pruritus
Rationale_Reason: safer antihistamines with fewer side-effects now widely available
Full_Text: First-generation antihistamines as first-line treatment for allergy or pruritus (safer antihistamines with fewer side-effects now widely available).

Condition_Disease: for insomnia
Rationale_Reason: high risk of side-effects, Z-drugs safer and more appropriate for short-term use
Full_Text: First-generation antihistamines for insomnia (high risk of side-effects, Z-drugs safer and more appropriate for short-term use).

Section: Section E: Renal System. The following commonly prescribed drugs are potentially

Section: Section E: Renal System. The following commonly prescribed drugs are potentially

Condition_Disease: with Parkinsonism
Full_Text: Prochlorperazine or metoclopramide with Parkinsonism (risk of exacerbating Parkinsonian symptoms).

Condition_Disease: for uncomplicated peptic ulcer disease at full therapeutic dosage for > 8 weeks
Rationale_Reason: dose reduction or earlier discontinuation or H2 antagonist maintenance therapy usually indicated
Full_Text: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for uncomplicated peptic ulcer disease at full therapeutic dosage for > 8 weeks (dose reduction or earlier discontinuation or H2 antagonist maintenance therapy usually indicated). 6

Condition_Disease: with chronic constipation where non-constipating alternatives are available
Full_Text: Drugs likely to cause constipation (e.g. systemic antimuscarinics, oral iron, opioids, verapamil, aluminium antacids) with chronic constipation where non-constipating alternatives are available (risk of exacerbation of constipation).

Condition_Disease: General/Unspecified

Full_Text: Oral elemental iron doses greater than 200 mg daily (e.g. ferrous fumarate> 600 mg/day, ferrous sulphate > 600 mg/day, ferrous gluconate> 1800 mg/day; no evidence of enhanced iron absorption above these doses).
